review_title: The Office of Alumni and Development is a hot mess
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great colleagues, advanced degree if you can stay long enough (2+ years to qualify + 3 years for program) to get it and can get accepted, benefits, vacation time. Working at the school level recommended, less dealing with OAD politics.
cons: Toxic work culture, the dysfunction comes from the top down.  The phrase "Bad managers fail upwards" applies to a lot of senior positions. As a result, there's lots of turnover. The Alumni Center is a pretty depressing place, you can tell people are really unhappy. They say they have work/life balance, but it really depends on who you work for. Low pay, stagnant salary raises. Salary raises are 1 to 2.5/3% and based on CORE values, which ironically the managers don't adhere to. To keep employee retention down, they eliminate positions when they fire someone or someone leaves. I definitely witnessed some unprofessional and immoral maybe illegal behavior. HR is a joke, go to the Ombuds office or leave if anything happens. Lots of politics, you won't always know why projects get scrapped or bad decisions made. There's a lot of scarcity mentality - upper management fighting over scraps and taking credit for rank and file work.  It's not uncommon to be yelled at by managers or other employees across the university. And if you go to HR, retaliation is a real possibility here. I have heard lots of stories of former colleagues dealing with some shady situations.

job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros: If you are an office of the University, your children get free tuition. If you are unmotivated or don't want to work hard, CU employees can slip through the cracks for years without anyone knowing or doing something about it. Without pressure to drive revenue, the mission is is loftier. The benefits are good: officers receive about 20 vacation days plus 3 personal days. In addition, the CU not only matches employee contributions to its non-profit version of a 401k, it also gives 5% of your salary even if you contribute nothing, and that money vests immediately. In terms of work and life balance, it probably varies from department to department, but for the most part my sense is that it's an incredibly flexible place.
cons: The pay is low relative to similar functional roles at for-profit companies. The only people who make average (or even way above average) salaries are those in senior management. For the 401K, the university has a good matching plan but make sure to try to enter as an office at grade 14 or above - the University won't match employee contributions for two years for officers at grade 13 or below. Also, this is not the right environment for a motivated, ambitious person. It's filled with cronyism and incompetence at many levels throughout the organization. And this can lead to very low morale among the rank and file.

review_title: Experience is heavily dependent on supervisor
job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
- Working at a prestigious institution
- Learning and acquiring knowledge about research
- Location is nice
cons:
- Administration very difficult to navigate - particularly HR in the place where I worked
- Pay is very low
- In my case, workload was tremendous and disproportionate to the amount of pay and hours I was receiving. Often times I would be asked to do things after hours even though I was told that it would be a 9-5 position (there is no compensation for work done outside of these hours).
- Little to no support from supervisor - this is dependent on where you will be working.
- Watch out for red flags from supervisors who say that they don't do timesheets. It might seem convenient to not have to do them until you find that you're being asked to stay late when your regular shift is 9-5. This should be reported to HR.

job_title: Officer of Administration in New York, NY
pros:
I have worked at two Columbia University administrative departments across all three campuses. There are several pros and cons to Columbia. Here are the pros:

- Good vacation policy, unlimited sick leave, good work-life balance
- Good retirement benefits. You immediately vest in your retirement plan and the university matches 3% of your voluntary contributions.  After two years as an officer, the company matches an extra 5%. 
- Lots of free food, lots of events
- Great tuition benefits
cons:
Columbia University pays below market rate compared to other universities and hospitals in the area. In asking my peers that work at other institutions, the pay can range up to 30% less at Columbia. A lot of my colleagues leave for other institutions, and the turnover rate at Columbia is very high. There is no stability and projects are left unfinished. Other people have to pick up the slack, often starting projects from scratch. 

It is a fast-paced environment -- while great and lets you learn a lot in the short amount of time-- also makes you question the low salary for the amount of work you are doing. 

Management does not seem to have a clue or don't seem to care to improve things, unfortunately. In the past 2 years, there has been a complete change of staff within the department I am currently working for.

review_title: Great benefits, below average pay, lots of bureaucracy
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Tuition Remission, Broad set of challenges, Exposure to multiple facets of the entire school. If your career goal is to grow fast and continue growth, then this is an ideal place to get in, get a degree, gain valuable work experience and then leave. Good work/life balance. Job security.
cons: Extreme budget constraints, the top decision makers (ie. faculty and dean) have unrealistic expectations due to the extremely limited budget they supply. There is always a do more with less approach, and while this is good for the sake of efficiency, there comes a point where it is just extreme. Upper management has no real backbone for creating policies and enforcing them. Extreme political forces at play here and lots of employees are undervalued.

job_title: Systems Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Columbia has great benefits and time off.  Very flexible and has great training opportunities.  On the tech side going to conferences the prestiges value is extremely helpful. Great people and community to help with my skills.  Free subscription resources to online materials like Lynda.com and digital books.
cons:
The pay at the university is less than businesses.  Columbia has a sense of you should be honored to work here.  The tech is not updated and many things are not current or state of the art.  Budgets need to be kept to and do not change much year to year. 
All departments are not unified. This means every department and section of the main IT unit are separate.  Working in a place where everything is seprate is hard and sometimes more costly since there is redundant contracts.

review_title: In Central Admin it's all about Power.  The only way to succeed is to CYA and say "Yes"
job_title: Executive Director in New York, NY
pros: Good pay, good benefits, great prestige being associated with this institution.
cons:
- Very territorial and bureaucratic.  
- So many people are fearful, and do things the way they've always been done.  
- Senior management in Central Admin (esp. top Finance leadership) is unwilling to hear any kind of problem or solution or approach unless they've thought about it themselves first.  
- It's a command-and-control environment, so you don't get much context about what's going on... you work on a need to know basis.
- Senior Finance management is deceptive and treats people poorly: Publicly ridicules direct reports, displays distrust of direct reports, grants vacation time grudgingly (and you have to ask three times), has only negative things to say about others, won't answer personnel matters that are important to you.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: 32.7% Fringe Benefit rate! This includes the famous tuition exemption for you, spouse, and children from primary school through graduate.  No one can beat this perk which allows you to develop and grow as a human being and professional.  Plus CU has numerous classes and on-line venues to access at your leisure and still receive credit.
cons: CU often employees Directors who have less of an education or little-to-no knowledge of their teams responsibilities.  Many qualified people leave CU because their immediate leadership is insecure, is less credentialed, and/or does not support staff development.  CU has yet to develop a culture of "having experts on your team" to make you success and in turn them successful...and then letting them leave the nest if they so desire without feelings of bitterness.

job_title: Assistant Director of Human Resources in New York, NY
pros: The Columbia name, the compensation and benefits are attractive. The size of organization allows for mobility and advancement if you want to grow professionally.
cons: After eight years at CU and having worked in 4 different departments, some departments/schools are better to work in than others. Overall as an institution, it still operates paper heavy, it would help to bring it more online and create better e- systems. There's a need to modernize more and invest in new programs, software, systems, etc., so we can be more efficient in how we run as a university/school/department. There's a lack of clarity on what the policies are among different departments, including the central offices where the policies come out of. This causes too much time wasted on trying to figure out how things should be done. Even some of the policies that are written down are too vague, unclear or confusing. While other polices don't exist in writing but really should.

review_title: Awesome research environment but terrible comps and rights
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros: A lot of labs working on very cool research projects. Brilliant and supportive colleagues.
cons: Postdoc salaries in biomedical labs at Columbia are pathetic. They follow the NIH guidelines, but don't adjust for the fact that the cost of living in NYC is ~150% higher than average of major US cities. Postdocs who manage to get grants for themselves end up getting LESS money than they would have if they stayed on their PI's grant, AND Columbia demotes their health insurance to the worst option possible. PIs and the administration often cite "prestige" to bully postdocs into accepting low salaries. "Prestige" doesn't pay for rent or food.

review_title: Ivy League status make Columbia abusing the young scientists looking for a carrier
job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in New York, NY
pros: Correct benefit, surround by some of the best scientists in the world who are working here or come to give talks, prestigious name, exciting city
cons: Salary is way too low compare to the cost of living in NYC. Columbia University is not supportive with the employees (one of the biggest building owner in the city but provide for the post-doc only few terrible and every expensive apartments), salary raise are control, HR office is a disaster trying to protect the company instead of helping their employee. If you don't have a good advisor (which fortunately is not my case) you are alone to face them.

job_title: Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros:
Top experts in the field
Great seminars and grand rounds
cons:
Absolute nightmare of an administration. Nobody cares and is willing to help until you've exhausted yourself in begging. 
So much red tape to do anything including running animal experiments. Took 6 months to get a simple IACUC protocol up and running.
People are generally overworked and cold; but keep at it because they're all driven to succeed.
NYSPI was designed to be a prison. You can feel your gray matter dissolving as you work non-stop in an isolated office with no windows and a faulty ventilation system.
As a post-doc, forget about rising up and surviving at the faculty level. There is ZERO space and no state lines left. And no one will ever help or support you - faculty couldn't care less whether you died or not (and I worked with 3 PIs)
Health insurance is confusing and mostly useless
I honestly wasted 8 years here and now have an anxiety disorder and taking a mix of lexapro and lorazepam. Thanks, CUMC!

review_title: My experience at Columbia is horrible, for an Ivy League institution ALL of their administrative staff is horrible.
job_title: Senior Benefits Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Decent tuition benefit if you have children going to college and they can either (a) make it into Columbia University or (b) your income is too high to get government assistance for your child go to a 3rd party school. If you want to work in the same job, same position, same responsibilities for the next 30 years of your career and you like lazy people who do not care about doing their jobs well.
cons: Benefit cuts are coming, tuition is the only benefit that is still somewhat good but that will go too. Management is horrible. No promotion opportunities. Alot of "lifers" with no incentive or motivation. A lot of broken / old systems. Negotiate a good salary because once you get there you are not getting anything. Their system for increases is as follows this year 2% for everyone who makes above a certain $ amount in a certain salary grade and more for those who make below a certain level. No performance is taken into account.

review_title: Work here if you have something you're personally working towards. Otherwise you'll be spinning your wheels.
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Great campus. Convenient location. Easy to commute to. Very reasonable time off & goog selection of benefits. Access to libraries. Inexpensive gym on campus.
cons: Complete lack of communication between schools. Tons of wasteful spending. No oversight of Dean's excessive spending. Tons of illegal non-competitive job bidding. Nepotistic insider hiring. Terrible salary increases. Lack of quality food choices on campus. Confusing bureaucratic red-tape in dealing with HR. Constant trying to skirt/lack of knowing union rules. Expressed disgust for staff. No clear whistleblower policy or way of reporting malfeasance.

review_title: A great place to work if you want to help others who help others.
job_title: Benefits Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Columbia University is a diverse environment that stimulates learning, teamwork, and a sense of accomplishment. As a support function, you're working behind the scenes to insure the professors and doctrs can concentrate on educating and changing the world. The benefits package is very extensive and Columbia subsidizes most of the cost. The greatest benefit is the ability to gain an Ivy League education at little to no cost to yourself.
cons: There are times when Management is caught up in politics. Egos can be easily bruised, and it is wise to mind who you cross as that person will find a way to get back at you. People stay in their positions for years and feel a sense of entitlement. They withhold information because they think it will make them obsolete. It can be a long commute depending on where you live.

review_title: Social Work Live Support Specialist (Online Campus)
job_title: Live Support Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Good retirement plan, easy enough work, decent pay, and you get to work from home. Also, it's great to work with some of the professors and associates.
cons: Management has become awful. Micromanagement is an understatement. I plan on quitting once the semester is done because it's not worth the frustration. They also make you complete unpaid training that requires hours of work weekly for over a month. Also, they can't guarantee you'll even get a class. I've been working here since the start of the Live Specialist position and I had to beg to get a class this semester.

review_title: Great place to work---for faculty or medical professionals
job_title: IT Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Great benefit-free tuition at Columbia that is if you can get accepted for part time degree programs otherwise you can take free individual classes in any discipline). Flex time can be worked at some departments. CU has a relaxed atmosphere for the most part, good work-life balance, autonomy and lots of room for creativity in your position. It offers an unparalleled, beautiful campus with lots of historical buildings and architecture. The libraries are an amazing place to study, read, etc.
You also learn alot from exceptional, highly educated individuals. Most would be categorized as great researchers, academics, medical practitioners but not good managers or senior managers.
cons: There is not much advancement for non faculty or medical staff positions. The pay rate is generally 20-30K below market.

review_title: Staff Positions are Boring, but You'll Be Treated Well
job_title: Programmer in New York, NY
pros: They pay for schooling and if you enjoy the academic environment, it's one of the best.
cons: The way people are promoted is awful. It's political and seniority based, which leaves a lot of under qualified people at the top.  Also, the workplace is very stagnant - there's not a lot of room for growth or doing new things.  In the end, its more of an easy way to make money in a relaxing environment than it is to do something where you'll learn and grow.  It's definitely not a place for the intellectually curious (this is for staff positions, not faculty positions).

review_title: Incredible opportunities and a promotion-resistant environment
job_title: Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: Columbia University recruits some of the greatest minds on earth, so working there as an officer of researcher allows you access to truly brilliant individuals. This kind of opportunity is difficult to find and is not to be taken for granted.
cons: Columbia has a hostile attitude towards promotion in the academic positions. If the department wants to hire a position that the administration doesn't deem sufficient, the hiring does not take place. Also, the cache of working at an Ivy league school effectively allows them to pay less, a common practice, but one with serious consequences in New York City.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Despite the problems, you can find a way to squeeze out some good work here and a lot of the coworkers are driven and bright.
cons: Low pay for NYC, and an unbelievably incompetent bureaucracy. Columbia is a house of cards and they assume that people will just deal with it for the prestige of being there. Not worth it. Every time that I had to deal with benefits, payroll, IT, etc was a disaster. I was often told to contact people who did not exist - so I was just sending emails and phone calls to the abyss and my problems were never solved. These problems include not being paid for months on end, so it's not trivial. It does not feel like CU takes care of the employees at all. The buildings are also falling apart and very dirty because the custodians are not supposed to clean the floors unless you pay them extra and schedule it. ** This is for the medical campus. The Morningside campus is run dramatically better.

review_title: Tuition exemption makes it worth it
job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The admin positions are usually through a collective bargaining unit which offers perks such as free computer classes for you and your family as well as a tuition fund if you take classes at a different university. There's also a child care subsidy fund that gets split amongst eligible union applicants with children aged 12 and under. 20 vacation days, 12 sick days, and 3 personal days a year. There's also paid holidays for most major holidays. Set schedule of monday-friday 9-5pm with weekends off.
cons: Dependent on which department you work in, you may be limited in growth opportunities and would have to look towards other departments for promotional opportunities. Some supervisors micro manage. There's no overtime for union support staff. Starting salaries are also not as high or competitively priced as they should be considering the cost of living in the nyc metro area.

job_title: Professor in New York, NY
pros: Fantastic Brand.  Unbelievable access to movers and shakers. Incredible depth of research talent. Strong and respected leadership. Solid financials. Beautiful campus. Helpful librarians and electronic resources.  Very generous benefits. Highly flexible in terms of how I spend my time. Super smart students. Heart of New York City.
cons: It's a university with a 250+ year old bureaucracy, with all that that implies.  Space is at a premium.  Students can be a tad "type A".  You need to be a self-manager as there are not a lot of structured support processes - it is very easy to get lost in the system.  The tenure and promotion process is byzantine and we lose a lot of great people as a consequence.  It's also very siloed.

review_title: Concern for rank over education made my particular office very political rather than student-oriented.
job_title: Career Counselor in New York, NY
pros: Motivated students, some great colleagues, resources to do some innovative work, and the Columbia name
cons: Every office may be different, but Columbia in general has a very corporate culture that takes the focus away from student development (perhaps like many universities today), though other student services offices seemed to be more interested in that than our office, so the issue may have been with our leadership team. Also, the HR contact for my office who was supposed to be there to help employees resolve issues did not keep her conversations confidential (i.e., she relayed information to leadership), so the people in my office had nowhere to turn (unless they didn't mind being punished or fired). There was a lot of high turnover because people did not feel respected or supported.

job_title: Financial Aid Officer in New York, NY
pros: The benefits are amazing. As an officer I can take classes for free (have to pay the fees though), the health insurance is great, and time off is more than adequate (23 days and unlimited sick days.. manager's discretion though). The opportunity for education is priceless and any employees not taking advantage of it are insane!
cons: The salary is less than I wanted, but I think it's off-set by the benefits. The union makes everything more difficult and I feel like I don't have much opportunity to be promoted within my department for quite some time. I also feel that I could serve my department and the university better if my skills were utilized more- I am full of ideas to improve!

review_title: Center for Career Education- Buyer Be Ware!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Get the Columbia University name brand attached to your resume. Other than that, this organization has very few pros.
cons:
The "senior leadership" at this place is horrifying- overt nepotism, incompetence, enormous egos and tons of unnecessary work. 

Senior leadership team is a joke- a group of buddies who are overpaid, not respected and work hard at self-promotion and taking credit for that which they do not actually do. Rules are only applied to non-friends of the top management. Senior leaders belittle and demean employees because of their own deep insecurities and issues and get away with it because of friends made in HR. These folks would never make it one day in a real work environment. 

This is is the place to go if you want your career to die and be faced with all that is wrong with higher education/non-profit.

job_title: Business Process Analyst in New York, NY
pros: It was a very laid back atmosphere.  The offices were newly renovated back in 2012 and the new management had some great direction and strategy right before I departed.  Benefits package is pretty standard and solid with the exception of tuition benefits.  It kept changing on us plus it was almost impossible to apply it towards any meaningful degree program because it was quite strict.
cons: The new management is new for a reason: it's clear they needed new direction.  Also, working in higher ed administration within an Ivy League institution is quite unique.  They don't really feel like they have to be at the cutting edge or constantly develop new exciting administrative tech because they don't really have to compete for students.  The name sells itself.

review_title: LDEO is nice to its postdocs, assuming you aren't being harassed
job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in New York, NY
pros: I work at LDEO, which I believe has some of the best conditions at Columbia for postdocs - competetive salaries, ability to be co-PI (if not PI?) on our own grants, and generally a good environment.  My experience has been very positive.
cons:
Because our campus is so far away from the medical campus, where most postdoc support is based, it can be hard to attend postdoc oriented events.  Most of my negative feelings about LDEO are because, despite the good intentions and efforts of many people on campus, the directorate is much more eager to sweep any e.g. harrassment allegations under the carpet than to deal with them.
Also, career prospects aren't that good within Lamont, because the career path towards research faculty at Lamont leads to a position that is generally regarded by the Columbia teaching faculty (and the directorate) as inferior and undeserving of support (or so I have heard).

job_title: A/V Manager in New York, NY
pros: Great organizational competence and structure.  Incredible benefits and work/life balance.  Decent cost of living increases (approx. 2.75%/year).  Ability to move laterally and up between schools and departments.  Very driven/ambitious/intelligent student body and faculty.
cons: Very hierarchical/bureaucratic.    Poor management oversight, i.e. upper management can run amok with total disregard for benefit to the institution.  I have seen some abhorrent and unethical behavior.  However this is not prevalent throughout  and most likely depends on your department and who you report to.  University is located in an "iffy" part of the city. Still lots of homeless and crime in the area.

job_title: Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Columbia University is a top Research Institution with good benefits.  It will provide you with excellent opportunities to work with internationally known researchers in one of the greatest cities in the world.
cons: However, the institution is old and each department is like it's own fiefdom with its unique brand of politics and way of doing things within a very, very entrenched bureaucracy.  The worst of it, whether you are seeking an administrative, academic or resarch post is that there are long standing tensions between the academic and the administrative branches of the organization, that prevent the smooth operation of anything.  Also, the amount of work and pressure far exceeds what you would expect from the "Ivory tower" and does not seem worth it given the poor compensation, and poor physical work environment.  If you are used to corporate America in any way...this will be a shock to the system, to say the least.

job_title: Staff Associate in New York, NY
pros: The best reasons to work (speaking as a staff member, not as a professor) at Columbia are the people, who are by and large smart, talented, and motivated. Many of the support staff are getting degrees from Columbia along the way, so they're accepting lower pay for tuition benefits. Columbia has enormous resources, and the health benefits and associated other benefits are good.
cons: Columbia is an opaque organization that operates like a feudal state. It has a massive and slow-moving bureaucracy, despite a number of attempts to overhaul its financial systems. Its technology is about a decade behind that of its peers. There are blurry lines between administrative and academic leadership.

review_title: Wide Array of Upward and Lateral Movement
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Columbia has provided me with incredible opportunities to grow within the organization. Opportunity coupled with highly collaborative and supportive peers and colleagues has made it an incredible place for me to develop personal and career skills.
cons: Columbia is a venerable institution but as such creates an environment that can be very intimidating to navigate at first. The better one can learn the ins and outs of multiple groups and departments around the university the more success and opportunity you will find available. Learning the institution is in some ways as important as learning the work itself.

job_title: Resident Advisor (RA) in New York, NY
pros:
- Interacting with residents from around the world
- Building a floor community that you and your residents enjoy living in
- Free housing
- Get to be on campus early and late for training/move-out
cons:
- Some supervisors stress the wrong aspects of the position (paperwork over student support, for example)
- Training can be confusing and unorganized
- Some residents are just terrible people
- Going through college in a "fishbowl," i.e. worrying about how you are perceived and what you are doing 24/7
- Supervisors are not very good at hiring trustworthy, dependable RAs

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Health insurance is great, at least compared to the smaller firms I always worked for.  The education benefit is good if you plan to stick around for a few years.  35 hour work week.
cons: In my department, CUIT, professional growth was not encouraged.   Another problem is a "Not invented here" syndrome.  CUIT is full of a staff that took advantage of the Columbia education, plus years of experience, but their knowledge and capabilities is rarely, if ever sought out.  Even if you are a good manager, it is difficult to be one in this environment.  I cannot talk to the experiences of life in other departments or schools of Columbia.

review_title: salary low for research scientists, but lots of perks
job_title: Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros:
- health insurance for the entire family is not expensive
- work-related expenses are covered generously
- lots of special resources to help people with all kind of problems
- tax-free benefits for childcare, $2000-$3000 extra for childcare
- tax free transportation
- lots of discounts in local shops
- retirement fund, employer also contributes
- Overall, this company is idea for couples and families in which the partner has a complementing "unsafe", low-benefits, high-paying job.
- I would think that non-researchers get much better salaries than researchers.
cons:
- forced union membership will come soon. My estimation is that it will cost $1000 and only bring about some special perks I don't need
- Sometimes I would prefer to just get a much higher salary than lots of perks.
- big bureaucratic body with lots of rules and paperwork
- I would think that non-researchers get much better salaries than researchers.

review_title: Great job security, staff positions (non-faculty) have generally limited growth potential
job_title: Program Manager in New York, NY
pros:
I'm writing from the perspective of a full-time staff member on a comm/marketing team for a school at CU. 
• Predicable 9-5 hours, which could be great for anyone w/ kids
• Tuition reimbursement, though unlikely to lead to an additional degree as you are limited to a class or 2 per semester.
• Great health benefits
•  Generous vacation policy
• Flex time working hours
cons:
Limited growth potential. Unless you have some sort of adjunct faculty position or connection/working relationship with a very senior director, you will likely be relegated to annual cost of living wage increases and the occasional merit increase if your department budget allows.
• Lots of "lifers" -- people who would not make it in more competitive private sector jobs. 
• No real office perks. Not a creative working environment, generally speaking.

review_title: EdLab -- A Wonderful Place to Work
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: The people who work here are great! Everybody is nice. They are also intelligent, highly competent, and highly motivated. It's not a place where you have to watch your back. The relationship between management and employees is excellent. It's an enlightened workplace.
cons: Any University is a bureaucracy, but as a unit of Teachers College, which is a unit of Columbia Universiy, EdLab employees are shielded from the cons of that bureaucracy to a very large extent. Although my compensation was more than fair, and I certainly enjoyed plenty of vacation time, the health benefits are not great. This is in keeping with the nationwide trend.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
World-class research opportunities
The library system can get you almost anything, even if Columbia does not have it
Superstar professors as mentors
Talented peers
Diverse and inclusive social environment
Plenty of opportunities for personal development
Active institutes putting on countless talks throughout the year
Talented undergraduate students make for memorable teaching experiences (for teaching postdocs)
cons: Postdocs are neither graduate students nor full faculty, so they can find themselves somewhat socially isolated. Colleagues tend to be busy with their work, so one needs to work hard at making connections.

review_title: As a PhD student in the CS department, I work hard, but learn a ton.
job_title: PhD Student in New York, NY
pros: The CS department is great and growing. You get to learn from excellent professors while living in New York City. The city attracts great talent-- you'll see good talks from famous academics, you'll have access to (some) tech companies nearby, and conferences will often be hosted here.
cons: Beyond any of the usual problems of being a PhD student... Columbia has a huge bureaucracy that is a drag when you have to deal with it for some minor issues, such as facilities problems. It also doesn't have a huge technology media apparatus, like MIT or Stanford, so it's harder for your research to get a lot of publicity. The lack of guaranteed funding over the summer, while great in encouraging internships, can make things tricky in later stages.

job_title: Systems Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: I work in the IT department for one of their school. My direct manager was great to work with. The hours were reasonable for IT, no crazy weird night and weekends. Interview was straight forward, no micro management and chance to take classes.
cons: Too much politic. The dean was the biggest problem, he did not know anything about IT and treated the IT staff like second class citizen. The workload can get overwhelming as you can have as little as 2 -3 week or winter break to redo 3 floors, 6 labs. Also no career growth, where you started is where you are staying and salary are much lower normal for the industry but in line with working for a University in NYC.

job_title: PhD Student in New York, NY
pros: In theory, we get to be compensated for researching and teaching subjects that we love. Travel is encouraged. And the caliber of the students we teach is rather high.
cons: Columbia is a bureaucratic nightmare. In order to get approval for the meager fellowships and stipends that are offered to graduate students, we are required to submit several detailed applications and forms and reports. None of the fellowship money is meant to be used for personal expenses outside of lodging and food (don't ask where you are supposed to find money to pay for basic toiletries). And there are not enough hours in the week to account for the amount of teaching/grading/research/coursework that is asked of the students.

review_title: Great place to advance your career and work with some thoughtful people.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Connections to people to help advance your career. You have the opportunity to work with people who are thoughtful about their topics of interest. Some ideologues, but overall the people seem open minded. For better or worse, being involved with a big name school helps you since people view it as a big deal. Living in New York can be fun and is at the very least a unique experience.
cons: Living in NY is expensive. This is only a downside if you are not a "go-getter" but, you have to seek out your own opportunities to do interesting or meaningful work as no one is necessarily going to hand you things...Just like any place else really.

review_title: A place to go when you are thinking about retirement and/or family
job_title: Applications Systems Developer in New York, NY
pros:
- Low stress
- Supporting a university feels a bit more like working for a non-profit, which is rewarding.
- Tuition reimbursement for you and immediate family
cons:
- Lowered expectations. Do not expect your co-workers to be stellar. Do not expect a challenge
- Sometimes it feels like you are living in a Dilbert comic
- Salary is laughable

review_title: Very Disorganized, experience depends on PI
job_title: Technician A in New York, NY
pros: Nothing is better than being at one of the best research institutions in the world. Well funded researchers are granted a lot of flexibility, which can be handed down to their technicians. As someone who plans to pursue a PhD after working as a technician, the networking possibilities were invaluable.
cons: Columbia can't seem to support it's own weight. The bureaucracy is insufferable, getting trained in and hired took over a month, but that was in part a problem of my PI. Being in biology, the labs and offices are split between two campuses which makes commuting to meetings and appointments a headache. On average, techs at Columbia make less than other universities in the city.

review_title: The graduate student experience at Columbia University will be different for everyone.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: As a graduate student, lifestyle can be busy but is very flexible. Additionally, training is extremely good, and intellectual curiosity is strongly encouraged. Although individual situations are different, graduate students generally have a lot of freedom to pursue projects that they are personally interested in.
cons: Work as a graduate student is heavily dependent on the mentor. Faculty have extremely diverse management styles, so that everyone's individual experience will be different. If not matched with a mentor whose style suits one's personality, the experience can be quite difficult.

review_title: Facilities management at Medicial center leadership is deficiient
job_title: Project Manager in New York, NY
pros: celebration of monthly birthdays with free cake every month  is the only effort made to boost the severely sagging morale at this place
cons:
cramped work spaces, with some staff stuffed into empty old apartments instead of professional office environment
senior leaders are very disrespectful of project managers time with constantly rescheduled and cancelled meetings, sometimes showing up up to 30 minutes late, sometimes never showing up at all- without any explanation.
 Extremely high turnover- 4 managers have quit , each staying less than a year on the job.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Prestigious. If you come here, you can actually stand a chance on the academic job market.
cons: Not enough money to live in New York City comfortably.  Most people qualified and eligible for the fellowship come from privileged backgrounds and have independent wealth to bolster their Columbia salary. This is the only reason there are not more complaints about how little we make. If you don't have savings or a trust fund, you will eat ramen noodles and not be able to go out to brunch with everyone all the time.  It isn't impossible but it makes medical emergencies a killer on your bank account and most of your peers will go on regular international vacations that you cannot afford.

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The school provides a great research platform, and the interactions with professors are very nice. If you want to apply for PhD programs (accounting, finance, economics, operations, marketing etc.), it is a great opportunity, because your bosses, the professors, they write good letters for you, and they are well connected.
cons: The pay is not compensating the almost investment-banking like hours. The work can be intensive and demanding as much as rewarding. You learn a lot, but be prepared to work really hard for a year or two.

job_title: Professor in New York, NY
pros:
Quality of students and faculty is outstanding 
Open, collaborative environment
Emphasis on trans-disciplinary research
Freedom to pursue a variety of research and teaching arenas
Location in New York provides access to a very stimulating community, the arts and finance
cons:
Administration is dysfunctional and there is increasing bureuacratization
Too much emphasis on generating externally funded research
Aging infrastructure and weak internal support for administrative functions
Need to run your own small enterprise to overcome the operational challenges and limited financial support from the school

job_title: Human Resources Director in New York, NY
pros: This is a very large decentralized large organization however you are able to get expert assistance from the central enterprise when needed.
cons: I really feel like the pay is very low for a large NYC organization -- even for a university the salary is on the low side.  Also, some of the staff who hold key positions and have been there for 30+ years tend to be less generous and/or forthcoming with knowledge about practices at CU.

review_title: Good students and faculty, terrible administration
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros: The students are hardworking, engaged and smart. The faculty is generally very high calibre and there are lots of interesting events and research projects happening on campus. Subsidized housing in NYC is nothing to scoff at.
cons: Hands down the most poorly managed university bureaucracy I've encountered. Many people in the administration are straight up rude; others seem to be doing the bare minimum required to retain their jobs. Lots of misallocated resources with no accountability. I really can't stress enough how disappointing my experience with the Columbia administration has been. I can only attribute it to either outright incompetence/corruption, or the arrogant attitude that comes from being an Ivy in a big city. My experience with administrators and bureaucracy at a much less well regarded state school was far better, which has honestly surprised me a lot.

review_title: Great work-life balance, but no advancement
job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The best part about this job was its generosity in giving time off - sometimes I would come in under the weather but ready to work, yet my supervisor would urge me to take a half day and relax.  In general, my hours were flexible and I could often work from home.  Compensation was good, though it was pretty clear that there wasn't much space for moving up or getting raises.
cons: While my department was tight-knit and fairly efficient, it was a nightmare to have to deal with anything outside of it - including liasoning with the office one floor down from us.  It seemed that separate departments made no effort to keep in touch, even if they often worked on projects together.

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: very good experience. Very nice faculty members. really really good working environment and people there. totally had a great time working with wonderful people. Columbia Columbia Columbia  Columbia Columbia Columbia  Columbia Columbia Columbia  Columbia Columbia Columbia
cons: can't think of any, to be honest. People are all very friendly and helpful. nothing too much to complain. Just need to focus on your job and you'll have a good time and learn a great deal!  Columbia Columbia Columbia  Columbia Columbia Columbia  Columbia Columbia Columbia

review_title: Very intersting place to work - very bright people with an oppressive bureaucracy.
job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros: Columbia has some good benefits overall, but the tuition and vacation benefits are the most generous.  There are many interesting people from a huge variety of disciplines, with corresponding great information and research.
cons: There is a huge disconnect between departments and it is terribly inefficient.  It is very difficult to find informaitn and to dig beneath the many layers of bureacracy to find the right people.

review_title: Great training ground for managing politics and navigating egos. You can build off your CU experience for advancement
job_title: Associate Dean in New York, NY
pros: Opportunity for impact in your niche and the education benefit for officers
cons:
Poor organizational design - highly decentralized campus, often duplicative and competitive services. I worked in undergraduate student affairs, politics often drove decisions and impacted organizational structure. 

Student body is overly entitled, not very resillent and many students have developmental challenges (psychological and emotional).

CU is not a supportive environment for administrators of color - racism is deeply embedded throughout the system. Micro-aggressions are the norm.

review_title: A university can be a nice and stable place to work
job_title: Columbia Giving Day Coordinator in New York, NY
pros:
- Good work/life balance
- Pretty good benefits
- Opportunity to interact with a diverse amount of people and departments 
- Stable employment
- Immediate supervisor worked hard to help me advance 
- Was very transparent and upfront about length of temporary job
cons:
- Lots of bureaucracy to wade through
- Takes a long time to get things approved, required to pivot quickly on concepts that may be close to being set  
- Mine was a temporary job that really should be longer term but the job had to be approved every year and was not considered to be a yearly essential
- Columbia, as a whole, is very siloed so it can be hard to interact across the university

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: If you are any sort of employee for Columbia, the benefits are excellent, with good medical insurance, dental coverage, vision riders, a relatively large amount of vacation time, nice 401(k) matching, and excellent educational opportunities.
cons:
Columbia has one of the ugliest bureaucracies I have ever dealt with. As an RA, I was generally isolated from that, but if you had to work in HR in the Interchurch building, I can imagine wanting to tear your hair out after a month.

The IT support could improve. They've been getting better, but it still has a ways to go.

job_title: Program Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Columbia University is located in Morningside Heights, which is beautiful. The university offers  great benefits and access to an amazing library and museums across the city.
cons: Depending on the Department, School, or Office where one is located, political maneuvering can proceed productivity. This may be an unworkable environment if one expects collaboration and the ability to take ownership of projects. Take it or leave it some offices are autocratic.

job_title: Lab Manager in New York, NY
pros:
-Ability to take classes for free(Once admitted into whichever program you choose)
-Exceptional student pool for research and mentoring
-Excellent talk series with openness between medical school campus and Morningside campus with regard to talks/conferences/research collaborations
-Work with some of the best, most innovative scientists and the talent they bring in
cons:
-The tuition remission program counts as taxable income- so the nearly $15k in tuition will result in much higher state and federal tax payments on your part.
-Some departments are bogged down by administrative problems.  You have to keep on top of them for submitting grants, visa renewals, contract renewals, etc.
-the pay is lower here than at other institutions in the city, to the point of it being unsustainable to work there and live nearby

review_title: Excellent Work-Life Balance, Competitive Salary, but Lacks Challenge
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: They provide reasonable, competitive salary, great benefits and work-life balance. I appreciate their tuition remission program as well. While it depends on which school/department you work at and whom you work with, I generally had positive experience with all of my colleagues. I like that I am working in the academia where I am contributing to the community of highly motivated faculty and bright students.
cons: I am still a young professional (in late 20's), and to be honest the slow-pace working environment and repetitive work can get dull sometimes. I miss the fast-paced, challenging work environment. Some administrators are not as motivated as you are, and can get things dragged on forever, which can be frustrating if you are ambitious.

review_title: Effective Director, But Limited Support for Student and Part-time Employees
job_title: Communications Associate, Executive Education in New York, NY
pros: Congenial office culture where everyone gets together to celebrate program launches, birthdays, even weddings. Free food and opportunity for professional development.
cons: Students from the school are often recruited to support staff for relatively little compensation. Furthermore, the office space isn't large enough to accommodate everyone on the days, and one sees that most clearly on the days when there are mandatory group meetings, and fewer people are working remotely. Many times I found myself having to work in the conference room, which destabilized the pattern of work.

review_title: Pay at Columbia University, Administrative Support Position
job_title: Program Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits, part of a bargaining unit and solid HR.
cons: Just like any admin job, there are set hierarchies and procedures to follow for promotion and for daily tasks.  They have a core value system throughout the college offices so they like to follow that and do professional and managerial development.  Use it to your advantage and take classes to develop your skill sets.  It's Columbia University for God sakes--they support "book learning"!  I took a few classes in my time there which was a great use of the employee benefit system.  It may have changed since I was there but they had a tuition remission program that was pretty good and cost effective, even for me.

review_title: Not worth it even for Ivy league
job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in New York, NY
pros: New York City, money, prestige
cons:
Very little concern for individuals, contracted and sociable work hours, work environment, communication, etc. Safety of employees was not really considered or enforced - 
 a major issue when working in the department of immunology and microbiology. There are no checks on supervisors  as long as they have grant money, they are more or less above reproach which does not make for a good laboratory environment.
 Obviously it is specific per laboratory, but overall the institution was not very well run with numerous departments that did not seem to speak to each other. 
My experience was in the Moscona Porotto laboratory which I found to be without a doubt the most hostile, disorganized, unsafe and wasteful laboratory I have ever experienced. Moreover, I found faithful and rigorous scientific research was discouraged in favor of fast, unchecked results.  Not good for further career in science.

job_title: Senior Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Columbia is a great place to be from.  Students need to be proactive about finding professors willing to bring them on as research assistants, but after that there are usually good opportunities to do interesting work and to co-author papers.  Most professors are willing to pay, which is great for undergraduates who are usually expected to work for free.
cons: The pay isn't great compared to other work-study jobs - I started at $8/hr and ended at $10, while people can make $12 for sitting and swiping cards.  Columbia infrastructure is notoriously bad, and my paycheck has been sent to the wrong place for literally two years.  Be prepared for red tape.

review_title: A solid program in solid state and electronic materials.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Located in New York City. Large number of active alumni and job placement services. Reasonably nice facilities: fully loaded clean room, XRD, SEMs. Bright, reasonably friendly, but not diverse graduate student population.
cons:
Materials Department is limited in scope to solid state and electronic materials research. Vast majority of research is computational with few experimental characterization/manufacturing facilities. 

Morningside campus is not particularly safe after dark. The organization is large and generally slow to respond.

Residence in NYC is expensive and limiting on the stipend.

review_title: rare that management is FOR the employee, there is a bureaucratic atmosphere
job_title: Executive Assistant in New York, NY
pros: great co-workers. helpful peers if you are lucky. the ivy league name. Okay area.
cons: low pay compared to state schools that pay more to perform the same exact duties. managers do not train staff, they are usually more tenured managers who can no longer train staff because they stay past retirement age and do not have that energy, as they have so many other things to manage. human resources do not step in to help when staff have complaints, they sweep things under the rug to maintain order and face.

review_title: All the great minds you could ask for... but you have to know what questions to ask.
job_title: Graduate Student/Research Assistant in Palisades, NY
pros: It's a top research institution. You have access to some of the best minds out there. It's also conducive to interdisciplinary research. The location, just outside of NYC, is pretty great - it's perfect for city people (commute by bus) or country people (live in the boonies, commute by car).
cons: Nobody tells anyone anything! There are few written guidelines and lots of ad hoc rules. Formal vacation days are a pretty new thing. Also, dealing with Columbia University itself can be a challenge.

review_title: Good work-life balance, but one must be cut out for a career in higher education
job_title: Program Coordinator in New York, NY
pros:
- good work-life balance
- a great place to work if one has a family and desires a 9-5 job with decent benefits
- benefits usually include the opportunity to take classes
cons:
- Working in small offices provides limited upward growth potential; most individuals need to move to other offices to be promoted
- Few opportunities for promotion or rewards or recognition for excelling at one's job
- Like many academic institutions, individuals who want to make change or "shake things up" or are ambitious will often encounter bureaucracy and some apathy among staff members

job_title: Project Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: My office was very laid-back. Very little micro-management, you were given assignments as a long as they were completed everything was fine. Very understanding of supporting the work/life balance. The sick leave and vacation was extremely generous when compared to other workplaces.
cons: Because I worked in a very small department there was limited opportunities for growth. So you would either have to remain pigeon-holed in that position or wait for someone to move on in order to advance. This was a great position for starting a career but not a good one for the long-term

review_title: It's a great, poorly managed university.
job_title: Graduate Student in New York, NY
pros: The research here is top quality and the atmosphere is very collaborative. People in outside labs are very willing to work with you. Classwork is top quality. You're also in the middle of New York, which is nice.
cons:
The management is scattered and chaotic. There are too many departments, none talk to one another. This makes it difficult to get many basic things done. Things like being paid on time.

Also, the shared equipment exists under weird layers of obscure management and much of it is of sub-par quality. Great research doesn't necessary take great equipment, but it sure helps.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Excellent resources.  Some labs are conducting cutting-edge research and there are opportunities for stellar publications.  Most peers are very friendly and willing to help one another.
cons: Work-life balance is very difficult.  It is expected that a fellow will work many hours to complete his or her project.  A fellow is technically not an employee of the university, so benefits may become an issue, particularly if you have a spouse or family.  The pay for a fellow is very low and is extremely difficult to live on in New York City.  It is also expected that you will not be promoted to Assistant Professor for many, many years after being a postdoc or similar level.

job_title: Assistant Director, Leadership and Civic Engagement in New York, NY
pros: Some very bright and caring students. Mid and entry level staff are generally good and support one another within your own office.
cons: Terribly competitive and toxic among students and upper level administrator. My passion is education, and Columbia was an example of when egos and self-interest trump progress and the purpose of learning. Ended up with mental health issues and advise of therapist, doctor, and partner was to leave as soon as possible.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great school. Excellent smart, hardworking students and professors.Beautiful campus. Ample time for research. .. ..  .  .  .  ..  ..  ... ..  ..  ..  ..  ..
cons: None that I can think of.   .   .   .   .  ..  ..  ..   .  .  ..

review_title: A very good place to teach and learn.
job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor  in New York, NY
pros: The openness, resource and knowledge in such a research and higher-ed institution.  All that smart people -- professors and students.  Being part of the knowledge-quest keeps you on the edge, and gives you continuous exposure to new developments, young fearless minds. Horns my teaching and performing skills of course. A nice change to a regular full-time R&D job.
cons: Hardly any career-advancement , since this is a part-time teaching job. Heavy workload considering it's merely an addition to another full-time job. Rather complicated logistics and bureaucracy in the supporting functions.

review_title: Teaching assistant in large (180+) core curriculum course.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros: While it is a standard doctoral support option to become a teaching assistant in a large undergraduate course, I found it rewarding to be on the team of 6 teaching assistants and to have close access to a world-leading faculty member.
cons: It was frustrating at times to defer course management decisions to other TAs with little or no teaching experience, but more content knowledge.

job_title: Senior Consultant in Springfield, MO
pros:
Good on-boarding orientation.
Very nice physical and office environment.
Nice, big, diverse group of colleagues, faculty and staff.
Working with hardworking and bright youth.
Decent benefits.
cons:
Low salaries vis a vis cost of living.
Executive offices occupied by status quo-only bureaucrats steeped in the hierarchy's politics, i.e., nothing changes, lessons are not learned.
Ivory tower aspect to faculty-staff relations.

review_title: Easy part-time work opportunity for students
job_title: General Assistant, Bibliographic Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
Easy part-time opportunity with permission to complete coursework while on the job (although this time is insubstantial due to recent departmental changes)
Decent pay
cons:
Difficult to be hired as a student without Federal Work Study status.
Recent university-wide student wage raises resulted in libraries consolidating different jobs into one position at Butler Circulation desk, making employment at that desk more difficult than in other libraries.
Poor training and oversight, so certain employees will bear more of the employment weight than others.
At the time that I was working, student employees with promotions in the form of raises and advanced training lost that pay distinction while still having to do advanced tasks compared to coworkers.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in New York, NY
pros:
Wonderful school with great resources available to the sciences. It's hard to speak broadly about the University as a whole because by the time you're getting your PhD all you see is your lab and your department. 
But, in terms of the faculty and facilities available it's my impression that a student in pretty much every discipline here will have all the things necessary to complete his/her research. The rest is up to you.
cons: It's a beautiful campus the the neighborhood (Morningside Heights) is a bit vanilla. I don't think there's anything that Columbia can do about this per se, but it's well worth your time to escape Morningside as often as you can

review_title: great resources but terrible bureaucracy and broken pay-scale
job_title: Program Officer in New York, NY
pros: intelligent colleagues, access to fantastic resources and events in the university environment, flexible working environment, really great vacation, insurance, and sick leave benefits
cons: Some of the worst bureaucracy I've ever seen, and my research focuses on government offices of developing countries. Colossal delays in processing payments. Extreme difficulty moving pay grades from the one used at your time of hire, meaning little room for upward growth and salary increases. Ineffective at disincentivizing poor management

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in New York Mls, MN
pros:
-Get to work and learn from the best scientists in the world.
-Lots of opportunities to attend seminars and classes.
-Housing in the downtown campus is excellent and cheap.
cons:
-Departments lack communication within itself and with each other
-The paper works required to get paid or get benefit are too convoluted. Experiences with not getting paid for a month or getting drop from health coverage is widespread.
-The facilities are old.

review_title: Highly Bureaucratic, inefficient and a lot of politicking- be careful
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Colleagues across the university are wonderful, Columbia has no problem attracting top talent, lots of vacation time and decent healthcare coverage.
cons: Highly inefficient, bureaucracy, intense politics and larger than life, unwarranted egos. Also, senior management overly secure in their positions and don't care to support people unless it could threaten their job security. For those that are thin skinned, this is not the place for you.

review_title: Columbia University is a great place to work and study. Especially for someone who want to learn something when working.
job_title: Library Assistant in Bengaluru
pros: I work in a library, so the work environment is very nice and comfortable, the people there are also very friendly. Supervisor is very nice to me, maybe because I am a student. I also heard that as a full-time employee, one could take any courses for free, which is really attractive.
cons: I am just a part-time student working here, so I didn't consider about the promotion. Salary is quite reasonable for a student with $15/hr.

job_title: Lab Technician in New York, NY
pros: Excellent brand to have on CV. Opportunity to attend talks, such as the Nobel Prize winner in chemistry for 2018.
cons: You would never guess how much money Columbia has by the way it fails to support its research departments. Very limited resources; equipment is constantly breaking and shared across groups. Space is insanely mismanaged. HR failed to properly outline the overhead on my grant and I was let go without much notice.

job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros:
- Great team. It's important to gel with the team you sign on to as so much of your interaction will be with the team rather than the school as a whole
- Good work-life balance. The job does not require much commitment outside of working hours (9-5 generally)
cons:
- Promotions are limited to the department. Any job transitions outside of the department will be treated as a general hire.
- You need to be self motivated to not be discouraged by the sometimes indifferent employees.

job_title: Program Coordinator in New York, NY
pros:
Excellent health benefits and access to free courses.
A relaxed, academic work environment.
cons:
Columbia pays low but offers very good health and savings benefits.
Free tuition was also a plus for me, though I was given the runaround when I wanted to get a degree.
I also found it difficult to advance or move to another department.

job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros: There is room to grow within this large organization.
cons: Lots of red tape, it takes a long time (days into several weeks at times) to get approvals and get things done. Policies are often unclear. Instructions/directives/information can vary depending on which office you are speaking with. Decentralized among all the different schools/ depts. Lots of trying to figure things.

review_title: Overall good employer, pretty campus, good benefits.
job_title: Development Associate in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits - including free tuition.  University atmosphere attracts a lot of smart, intellectual people committed to education.  Many people stay at Columbia for a long time, as moving between departments is relatively easy.  For the most part the University is committed to retaining staff and encouraging professional development, and there are ample opportunities to build skills.
cons: Bureaucracy.  But no different than any other top-tier large research university.  Processes are not very efficient and things that shouldn't take a long time take forever.  This can be frustrating.

review_title: Great Place to Work, Grow and Develop
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Flexibility is key at the LDEO campus, it is a great atmosphere, thriving work, interesting and benefiting the community and world. very active lifestyles with soccer, volleyball, flag football, tai-chi, yoga and more offered at lunch time. On campus Cafeteria. Great benefits, lots of opportunities on various campus' for career growth.
cons: pay can be low depending on the position, if commuting from the city, there is a shuttle but it can take quite a while.

review_title: Value people who do the real work
job_title: Application Developer in Palisades, NY
pros: Benefits are some of the best and there is unlimited sick days off. Other benefits like employer match to your 401k depends on your tenure and seniority.
cons: Politics. Lack of coordination among different teams. No one wants to take ownership. Middle and Senior management is made up of people who have been there 15 to 20 years and are very hesitant to change and feel threatened about new changes or initiatives. Managers and directors are getting away with missed project deadlines by throwing the people who do the actual work under the bus.

job_title: Program Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Columbia University has great benefits including, tuition reimbursement, health care, housing, and transportation. You will also work with brilliant people.
cons: Unfortunately they routinely hire overqualified people to do routine jobs.  The space issues lead to isolation, and anyone in an administrative position is immediately looked down upon. In addition the institutional red tape will tie your hands in such a way as to add to the faculty thinking you are incompetence.

job_title: Executive Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Smart and kind colleagues, interesting, challenging and varied work, great benefits. Overall a terrific academic community of learners and teachers.
cons: Monetary compensation is low for the level of work performed, i.e. there's a 24/7 mentality without the compensation. Vacations are not truly vacations since its a trim operation administratively, and there is no one to cover for you.

review_title: Multiculturalism and diversity is limited in senior leadership roles.
job_title: Research Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: The name alone provides many opportunities and one is able to take advantage of attending presentations/discussions throughout campus. The vacation time is excellent as well.
cons: Racist institution that looks the other way when people of color are being discriminated against.  Several racist acts have occurred throughout campus in the past among blacks and Latinos.  The institution emphasizes that they encourage multiculturalism and diversity, but their practice places many barriers.  Staff are expected to conform and not challenge upper management.  Communication is from the top down, as well as performance evaluations (e.g., staff do not evaluate their supervisor).  Employee morale in my department was extremely low and high turnover.

job_title: Research Technician in New York, NY
pros: Plenty of smart and interesting people to work with.
cons: The noose of bureaucracy yearly continues to tighten. If you have the misfortune to be low on the totem of administration you will swing through a pendulum of anger, frustration and agony. A well-paid administrative bloc seems to continue to metastasize, while research employees labor for 'customary' low wages. As noted by other reviewers, it's difficult to ascend the power structure. But most vile- the salaries for support staff are far below what they should be- especially for an employer in a high cost of living metro like New York City.

review_title: I receive extensive training on research here. Good place for learning.
job_title: Graduate Student in New York, NY
pros: I work as a graduate student in Chemistry Department. My advisor and co-workers are all very nice and are always ready to help you solve any problems you have. Very good working environment! Very flexible work schedule, largely depends on your own working efficiency.  I will recommend this university to other people.
cons: The connection with various companies are not enough. Not many recruiting events around. The apartment renting is very very expensive, cost around half of your salary.

review_title: It is what you make of it
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: The University can offer great research opportunities. The financial support is respectable for New York City. The campus is beautiful, and location in the city is great.
cons: There is huge bureaucracy which is an impediment to getting things done. Not a lot of campus space. Students must be assertive not to get lost in the shuffle.

review_title: It was okay, but very much like many other office jobs.
job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: It is a large employer, which means there is room to grow, somewhat.  You get the benefits of being in a University setting, for those who are interested in taking advantage of them.
cons: It is a large and very decentralized employer.  This can be both a pro and a con, but it does mean that it can be difficult and time-consuming to get answers to questions and resolve problems, or even to know who to talk to, and the answer can often change depending on whom you are speaking with.  Some benefits have been cut in recent years.

job_title: PhD Candidate in New York, NY
pros: A lot of great opportunities to further your education, attend lectures, seminars and workshops from researchers at the forefront of their subject. Departments are close-knit and the people are generally friendly and willing to lend a hand when needed.
cons: Administration is very unorganized and there is a lot of red tape to go through to get things done. Lack of communication and coordination between administrations of different schools within the university, as well as between the school administrations and the university administration.

job_title: Program Director in New York, NY
pros: Columbia University is a leading university in New York City, they offer good child care, and education benefits for faculty and officers with children.
cons: Administrative management leaves something to be desired.  An overall lack of strategic thinking permeates the institution, though there are plenty of great departments, centers, etc which are better.

review_title: Tons of Learning, Very Little Growth
job_title: Web Editor in New York, NY
pros: The job is stable. Benefits are great, especially if you want to have or already have children. The tuition discount for yourself is also incredible. Plenty of opportunity to learn new skills or gain a new degree.
cons: There isn't much room for vertical growth. To get a real promotion and raise, you'd have to move to another department or have a boss who loves you. Environment is slower-paced because Columbia is a large, decentralized and bureaucratic institution.

review_title: Learned a lot of information regarding telecom, tech, and media industries.
job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
Learning an abundance of information pertaining to tech, telecom, and media industries. 
Teamwork.
Being amongst a large group of high-level scholars (pretty much everyone who interns there is from Harvard, Yale, Cornell, UChicago, NYU, etc.)
Free trips and lectures.
Just a good internship experience.
cons:
Low pay, if any. (interns do not get paid at all, completely voluntary).
Sometimes you get really irritating work to do.
Other than that, not many cons.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits.  Lots of interesting things happening on campus that you can attend at little or no fee.
cons: Very unprofessional environment.  More than one co-worker told me to slow my work pace because I would make everyone else look bad.  Getting anything accomplished was very difficult because it was an "everyone for themselves" mentality and most work was done at a snails pace.  Team building was difficult because everyone wanted to know what was in it for them and "what was best for the group/program/school" was not an acceptable reason to them -- they mostly wanted a financial incentive to work together.

job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros:
great benefits (unless they change, which is in process)
good work/life balance (but depends on manager/department)
cons:
everything moves slowly, inefficient, siloed, and bureacratic
not very challenging, goal-driven, which is ok for some if you want to just cruise, but if you want a stimulating, entrepreneurial environment, look somewhere else

review_title: Columbia University was a great blend of academic and work experience.
job_title: Senior Laboratory Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Excellent academic environment, plenty of jobs for students who need to make money for basic expenses, job availability within one's major department,  and experience building
cons: You can get sucked into having jobs that are just jobs and don't help with experience or one's career path. Don't take just any job, some of them are worthless for the student other than the money.

job_title: Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: Observe great opportunities for may future and my family. Work that every Citizen looking for improvement in this life that is very hard to find a Job.
cons: I see little chance if there is no any experience nor observed who observes and qualify with firmness.

review_title: Some of the Most Engaging Work I Have Done
job_title: Summer Research Intern in New York, NY
pros: The research I was able to engage in was extremely meaningful and at the cutting edge of my academic field. I was given free housing, and was given the amenities and resources that a tuition-paying Columbia student would have during the school year.
cons: The compensation was not the best, and there are some bureaucratic issues related to resources available at Columbia University.

review_title: Adjunct Lecturer, School of International and Public Affairs
job_title: Adjunct Lecturer in New York, NY
pros: Great laboratory for thinking and learning, with good opportunities to cross into other domains, schools and programs.  Great reputation and attracts interesting and successful people from all over the world.
cons: Can function in bureaucratic and inefficient ways along the lines of the stereotypical academy.  Resources, systems and information provided for adjuncts are at time well below reasonable professional expectations.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Great place to work - benefits include the option to take free classes through the College of General Studies,tuition benefits for your family, great healthcare plan, access to libraries and other facilities, flexible scheduling and association with a prestigious university. The people you work with will generally be very smart and at the top of their field. Columbia is also located in New York City, which is a huge boon.
cons: Pay at an academic institution is generally lower than what you would receive in the private sector.

review_title: Culture Matters but a poor overall working experience.
job_title: Systems Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Great chance to develop skills and grow.   Learned a great deal in a very short time.  Great Vacation Accural.   Chance to work with a lot of really smart people.  Great HR department.  Got a great parking spot for a good price.  35 Hour Workweek.  Diverse backgrounds.
cons: The starting pay was on the low end.  There was a lot of political challenges.  Poor working Environment, lack of good culture.

review_title: Great colleagues and intellectually engaging work environment at university
job_title: Administrative Director in New York, NY
pros: You are surrounded by smart people and ideas.  You can be involved in pushing the educational envelope.  In some departments there is a very collaborative feel. Often, there are opportunities to start new programs and be entrepreneurial. There are many opportunities to work with ideas and educational content.
cons: Things move much more slowly than in the private sector.  There is a big emphasis on consensus that sometimes slows things down. Some faculty do not seem to respect colleagues in administration. Resources are limited but it just means you have to be creative in managing your work.

review_title: it is NOT what you expect from an Ivy League place
job_title: Associate Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros: lot of driven people around you, strong community, access to proficient networking for advancement in career and in science (of course...)
cons:
LOTS of alpha-types without a real professional background to brag about (huge and sad discovery... beware), poor infrastructure for research, disturbing level of administrative red tapes, very low salaries particularly for the NY area, NO serious career progression (and surely the Deans and the Provost are not really into the problem)
Guys, Columbia is NOT what you expect as a student, as a PhD professional, and as a Professor. Not sure for administrative positions. Try Princeton or Harvard.
