review_title: It is excellent, professional, relaxed, caring, lots of opportunities to grow laterally and up.
job_title: Project Coordinator in Palisades, NY
pros: at the LDEO campus, lots of extra activities, yoga, basketball, soccer, volleyball. Since its through Columbia University you have access to classes, training, sobaticals, almost a month's worth of time off in a year. Flexible Hours, each position varies in the liberties but it is a very good company to work for.
cons: Pay is not what you would get elsewhere(such as Finance industry), but for a University it is very good.

review_title: Graduate school in the department of Applied Physics and Applied Mathematics
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: There are very smart faculty and students to work with.  The courses that are good are very good.  If you find a faculty member to fund you and pass your qualifying exam the PhD program is a great learning opportunity.
cons: Finding funding can be a bit tricky for some people, especially in a small department.  Transferring from the masters to the PhD program is difficult for many students.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: You get to interact directly with professor and take part in the education of the students. Develop an appreciation for your past TAs. Build a network with other TAs and find a smaller home within a large community. Good leadership experience, became informal mentors to many.
cons: Students are not always appreciative of their TAs; they don't understand the tough position a TA is put in as a peer but also as a supervisor. Salary bad.

job_title: PhD Student in New York, NY
pros:
University provides subsidized housing.
The university has its own security force with patrol cars that move around the campus and its housing.
cons:
Subsidized housing is still expensive because it is in NYC.
University has extremely annoying mandatory sexual respect initiative requirements that will take a decent chunk of your life away for nothing.

review_title: Decent job, surprising lack of infrastructure given level of university
job_title: Faculty Desktop Support in New York, NY
pros: Flexible hours, most faculty are friendly and gracious. I spent my time helping professors and administrators with their various computer problems. Most fell under similar categories and were thus easily resolved. I greatly enjoyed the ability to schedule my own hours and come and go as I pleased.
cons: Communication was sometimes difficult. Never got a raise. Sometimes it was frustrating having to wait for departmental approval to proceed with work requests, or to figure out exactly who was responsible for helping a particular client.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Full tuition benefits if enrolled in a degree program at Columbia University, and plenty of room to climb the ranks because of a bloated bureaucratic system.  Great place to get your career off the ground.  Good benefits.
cons: Low salary.  Bloated bureaucratic system is challenging to navigate successfully.  Lots of anachronistic inefficiencies.

review_title: Good place to work if you already do well in a large workplace with moderate bureaucratic inertia.
job_title: Development Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Great co-workers, great leadership/management, flat management structure where I was in the Graduate School of Business. Great ideas don't get stifled by old-school big ego-types.
cons: Workplace was not good for me as a person with diagnosed learning differences. I shouldn't have applied for this job, and they shouldn't have hired me. It's not just Columbia's fault; white collar workplace environments aren't yet ready to take advantage of the strengths differently abled persons have to offer.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros: Columbia University has a very good reputation (Ivy league!), I was working with very smart people, the funding situation was good even though the current general funding situation in the US is bad.
cons:
working long hours (12+) and working on Saturdays obligatory, very tense, competitive and disrespectful working environment. 
I love science, but this position almost completely spoiled it for me. I was very unhappy
at Columbia University and many of my fellow post docs in the same lab, but also in other labs, felt the same way. 
Columbia University housing (as compared to Rockefeller for example) not to be recommended.

review_title: Little support for graduate students and postdoctoral researchers
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Located in New York City
cons: University does not provide academic, career, or work-life balance support to graduate students. University does not encourage professors and graduate student advisors to actually advise their students. Graduate students are often disgruntled and cannot do anything about it because they have no platform for having their concerns heard by the university.

job_title: Associate Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros: Big, with so many PIs and research opportunities. Lots of intelligent people. Perfect for young scientist trying to figure out what to do. There is a lot of freedom to pursue research interests and to be relatively independent. This place is the path to academia professorship if you are smart, ambitious and lucky.
cons: Big. So big, there are so many bureaucracy and waste. Smart people come and leave. Whether you have a good experience is highly dependent on who is your boss. The benefits is OK, but the pay is on the lower side. Not good for long term staying.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: It's definitely a company that takes care of its employees; excellent benefits, employer-sponsored social events, location. Application process is very clean and straight-forward and allows you to know the pay scale minimum of each job you are applying to.
cons: It's a VERY strict hierarchy--not the casual type of employment.  Doesn't offer much room for growth as many positions are career-track oriented, so it's something to certainly keep in mind.  Be in it for the long haul.

review_title: Go to the best ranking school you can get in to but make sure your adviser is someone you like  and can work with
job_title: PhD Candiade in New York, NY
pros: As a PhD candidate I chose Columbia for the name as well as my adviser
cons: you trade 6 years making very little money for a few pieces of paper and a lot of knowledge with the hope that the investment will pay off in the long run

job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher  in New York, NY
pros: It's a great place to work and live.  Depending on your status as a researcher your sponsoring department/institute should provide you with housing that is very nice and relatively inexpensive.  The benefits package is also really nice with regards to the out-of-pocket cost of health insurance, especially in comparison to other comparable schools.
cons: The standards for work ethic are set very high and you might not have a lot of freedom to enjoy your life and family.  There is no retirement compensation for post-docs.

review_title: Great Benefits, But It Is the Place Where Productivity Goes to Die
job_title: Digital Media Project Manager in New York, NY
pros: Benefits were top notch. I had a fantastic boss at the Mailman School of Public Health. I enjoyed working with people around the school and being around so many great minds.
cons: Out of control bureaucracy, it took FOREVER to get anything done. Plus, when you went to Finance for help, there are so many rules they would call you back at least half a dozen times on each project, " Oh, and we didn't know this, but you're going to need this as well." Pure madness to accomplish anything.

review_title: Not too bad but not perfect
job_title: Graduate Student/Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: It is in New York City. There is a lot of money. It is a prestigious institution. There are good seminars and activities. Some of the students are very good. The facilities are not bad.
cons: The money doesn't necessarily get spent for the salary of the employees or for their health benefits. Some of the students are not the smartest and you wonder how the got there. There is a lot of competition. Some professors are very pushy. Lack of space because of location in NYC. The people working to take care of the facilities are totally incompetent.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: As a work-study student doing research, I get a lot of independence around the lab to help as I see fit. My schedule is incredibly flexible, which is great seeing as I can work it around my class schedule.
cons: The pay isn't that great - but it's a work-study so it's not technically the university paying me so that isn't exactly their fault. Top-down organization can make bureaucracy pretty annoying since the departments are incredibly decentralized.

review_title: Good pay, good benefits, develop a tough skin for egos
job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The plusses of working at CU are: the chance to interact with brilliant minds in research, the experience in getting your hands involved in more opportunities than other research employers offer, the prestige and boost on your resume.
cons: The downsides of working at CU are interaction with large egos, poor management

job_title: Regulatory Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: The benefits at Columbia University's Medical Center are great!  If you have a full time Officer position you get 4 weeks paid vacation, free tuition for up to 16 credits per semester, great retirement plan with company match after 2 years with CU, great medical/dental/vision plans.
cons: There is no organization within each department.  People work blindly with the hope they are doing things right.  No proper training and hope for promotion.  Unless you can utilize the benefits, it is not worth it to get stuck in this company.

job_title: Postdoctoral in New York, NY
pros: A great place to work. Collaborations quickly fructify. The entrepreneurial spirit among the scientist is unparalleled. Job prospects are better than other places due to its location in New York.  New York as a city has its charms which prove to be a magnet for Columbia University.
cons: High apartment rents. Long commute to work. Salaries may not be adequate for maintaining a decent lifestyle in New York City.

review_title: It is a great institution to work for but is a high intensity environment and a large bureaucracy.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: People are very driven and care a lot about what they are doing. Working in higher education is always fulfilling and you get to be involved in a lot of different things at the university.
cons: It reflects the personality of the city it calls home.  For the world of higher education it is a pretty intense place and there is not a lot of work life balance.  It can also be difficult to navigate the bureaucracy of an institution this large.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: I gained tremendously insightful experience about certain research topic. The co-workers were so nice. The supervisors were so nice. I recommend everyone to work here.
cons: The salary level was on the average level. You really need passion to support yourself to keep doing research here. There's no such thing call working hours. Your working hours are 24/7.

review_title: Unless you are a librarian do NOT work for Columbia Libraries!
job_title: Web Developer in New York, NY
pros:
The tuition benefits are the best part of working at Columbia. Especially as they cover your kids (school, Columbia, and even other undergrad colleges) your spouse can earn an undergrad degree too. Master's Program are good if you don't have one already but there are only a few part-time degrees available and they are not always ones that you are interested in and are somewhat mixed in as far as actually value of education and teaching.

Vacation is very good with 23 days as the standard starting amount.  
The health Benefits are good with a wide range of choices and optional vision and dental Plans
cons:
Incompetency of leadership especially in the upper echelons of  libraries. The 'Peter Principle' is in full effect here. The are also a lot of lifers here, unmotivated and incompetent people can eek out a long and fruitless existence with the bureaucracy. This is problematic if you work or even need to deal with them. 

Managers are too often picked for their subservience over their leadership abilities, vision, management skills or general competency.  Salaries tend to be very poor and those involved in the budgets are very cheap and do not understand ideas of value of bottom line especially when it comes to investment in technology.

review_title: A Jumping Stone to better things... not worth the stop...
job_title: Systems Engineer in New York, NY
pros: Depending on you upper management, you could have a very good work environment and Work/Life balance,  smart coworkers and dedicated supervisors.  Lot's of opportunities, if and only if you have a good supervisor or have know someone in upper management.
cons: Stop with the "Columbia" blame game, you have IT supervisors that have no IT knowledge, and they are driving internal IT Initiatives.  Directors have mentioned that they want to show that they have build a team from the ground up. They don't care about current employees and if your not in the same "Clique" you not going to advance.

job_title: Director of Academic Administration and Finance in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits and pension plan, nice to have gym and library on campus. Tuition Exemption, campus is pleasant.  Working with students.
cons: The bureaucracy has become cumbersome, most jobs involve being on a computer all day long every day, salaries are non-profit and the best people working at Columbia are tending to leave now.  Working with professors can be difficult.

review_title: Various Student/Part-Time Level Positions at Columbia
job_title: Various Student Level Positions Throughout University in New York, NY
pros: If you are a student here and/or need low-stress jobs, not a bad place to find such positions. May not be the most rewarding or geared towards deep, long-term professional development, but can make do and be framed to appear to do so if necessary/desired.
cons: Extremely disorganized, have serious widespread issues with paying its employees (especially students) on time/properly/proper or full paycheck amounts

review_title: A lot of behind the scene power struggles not visible until you're at the very top.
job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros: New York City is the most intense place you can find and has everything you can want or need...for a price.
cons: New York City housing is tremendously expensive on a regular academic salary.  If you are recruited without anyone that can stand up for you the first year it will be very hard for you to find your way through the morass of the very red-tape oriented administration.

review_title: wonderful students, larger staff than many similar offices, many hours - easy to burn out
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The students are wonderful and it feels like everyone strives for excellence.  Creates an atmosphere where people want to do as much as possible.
cons: Salary at certain levels are low, and it can take time to be promoted.  In addition, in some departments there is no room for professional growth because of the structure.  There is a lot of bureaucracy to implement new programs and ideas.

review_title: It was okay, but ultimately not for me.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Best reasons to work there are definitely the benefits. Numerous, affordable health insurance options. A salaried employee receives >3 weeks vacation days upon starting. That's something I've yet to encounter anywhere else. Room for lateral moves across university departments.
cons: The work-life balance wasn't the best. Those in my office regularly worked 50-60 hour weeks. Depending on your department, if you're student facing, the administration will let them walk all over you. Tuition benefit was greatly reduced, allowing only 2 courses per semester, if I remember correctly.

job_title: Work Study Student in New York, NY
pros:
- Staff is accommodating and understanding of student needs and schedules
- Friendly, cheerful staff with eyes on the goal
- Fast-paced but positive environment where students are welcomed for their contributions and professional development
- Staff is very willing to give recommendations and help students to success
cons: - It can be difficult to balance a work/study job with other priorities (eg social life, studying for classes, maintaining healthy exercise habits, etc) but it can be done with hard work!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Columbia University has very nice campus and working environment. The department I worked with provided lots of research opportunities. I was able to maintain work life balance, and my daily commute is easy.
cons: The university doesn't support H1B working visa for postdoc research scientists. Once you are done with your OPT, you have to be on J1 visa in order to continue your work. It can be troublesome later on.

review_title: You have to accept the good with the bad!
job_title: Project Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Excellent benefits package, which includes a degree from this prestigious university. If you have children, they will be able to go the university free of charge (of course that's if they get accepted)
Some manages are great at what they do.
cons:
There are strings that the come with education portion of your benefits. When you are recruited and you accept the job, there are details that are left out that you would never think of asking. You can only take a set amount of credits per year. If you exceed this number you will have to pay for it out of your own pocket. There are certain degree programs that Columbia will not cover. If you had you mind on a program please make sure that Columbia will cover the cost for you before you sign up to work here. 

The work environment may have you wondering if the benefits are worth it. There is a lack of decision making in the highest management levels. I cannot speak for it in all departments. Make sure you get everything in writing! Amnesia is prevalent in management levels. 
when the negative atmosphere builds up, you will consistently convince yourself that its worth it. You just have to stick it out.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros:
-New York
-Top place
-Easy to find collaborations

The postdoc experience mainly comes down to: did you correctly choose your PI. If you did not, it might be a living nightmare. If you did, like me, you spend a very great 4 years working on your ideas with a lot of support.
cons: I read a comment about salary. Well, it is a postdoc, there is no such thing as "market" value. Postdocs salaries sucks everywhere but still higher here than many other places. But New York is more expensive than other places.

review_title: Diverse benefits in a giant bureaucracy
job_title: Grants Manager in New York, NY
pros: Good family benefits including 6 weeks full pay for maternity leave for officers of administration, well developed support for families with child care or housing needs. Good opportunities for advancement and networking within the university once you’re in. Commitment to diverse hiring, good onboarding process.
cons: Siloed HR departments and a massive central bureaucracy mean it takes an amazing amount of time to get anything done correctly. Federal grant funding for research coming to the university leads to a CYA mentality that hampers process improvement. Unclear performance review process.

job_title: Senior Secretary in New York, NY
pros: I couldn't really think of any other than I guess experience.
cons: They prefer to give too much work to one or two people and blame them all the time than to hire extra help. Very few people are happy and the only ones that maybe are the higher-ups who are making the actual money. They treat the rest of us as if we are dirt while we do a significant amount of work that are real assets to the entire hospital.

job_title: Graphic Designer in New York, NY
pros: The staff is friendly considering it's a large mix of students and senior staffers. Since this is an academic facility, they are flexible about schedule.
cons: Seems to have more bureaucracy than necessary, even though people are mainly dealing with academic issues. Tremendous red tape and little recognition for many things you do since there are literally hundreds of other departments in the school

job_title: Finance Professional in New York, NY
pros: Excellent benefits, employment opportunities abound within; great people to work with (depending on department); great work/life balance.  Overall, CU is a progressive and forward-thinking organization with an abundance of opportunities for future growth and development
cons: Limited ability to express ideas; short-sigthed approach to management; a lack of "lead-by-example" leadership; inadequate experience of certain members in executive-level positions.

job_title: Executive Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Intelligent colleagues and really interesting and varied projects.  Beautiful campus which is a surprise considering you're in NYC.  Manhattanville exciting and explosive.
cons: Long way uptown from midtown.  The commute is a killer and there's not much uptown besides the University so you do feel a little out of the loop in the city.

job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in New York, NY
pros: Excellent work life balance, great culture push from HR. Nice events and party's periodically. Mostly laid back senior staff. The work is tough, but as long as you put effort in you'll stand out as there is undoubtedly some dead-weight throughout the teams.
cons: Most of the CUIT team has been moved uptown, away from campus. Its easy to forget that you work for a school because you're honestly stuck in a bubble far away from campus with zero students.

review_title: Great place to work and grow
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: I've been at Columbia for over five years. The Office of Alumni and Development is a great place to work! Great benefits, strong teams, and very collaborative culture.
cons: Columbia has a more intense pace then most higher ed institutions. While good work is valued and recognized, work/life balance can be a challenge.

review_title: A good job with good benefits and job security.
job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Benefits, Job Security, Good Direct Managers
cons: Need higher pay, additional staff, additional managers for the heavy workloads.

job_title: Project Coordinator in New York, NY
pros:
Salaries are decent. I'd say mid-range for administrative/research positions...for example higher than NYU but lower than MSKCC.

Despite its far uptown location, it's more accessible than you would think, at least from the West side.

Great reputation.
cons:
So much red tape, even compared to other med centers. The way HR is structured is particularly problematic. 

The benefits are significantly more expensive than at another med center I worked at.

Good luck commuting if you're coming from the East side. Also, the 1 train is literally only accessible via terrible elevators. There are no stairs, I kid you not.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: Columbia University has a good campus vibe, good intellectual atmosphere, good range of students and great library facilities. It also has good retirement benefits and reasonable health insurance plans.
cons: The administration is extremely uncooperative and extremely hard-to-navigate bureaucracy makes life often very difficult here. If you are a foreign scholar, expect even worse.

review_title: Look for red flags during your interview
job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros: Excellent health benefits, generous vacation
cons: Stagnant salaries, shrinking benefits

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros:
Columbia Univ is a worldwild well-known University w/ a lot of big shots in biology resaerch field;
A variety of reserch facilities make work easier and save your time;
cons: The communication within the Cancer Center has A LOT of room for improvement; collarabation is lacking as well. In general, it's not a very vibrate place for research which is hard to believe but true! Benefits are not very attractive. But a lot of vacation days, only if you can use them.

review_title: Good work environment, lots of deadweight
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Pleasant work environment.  Friendly coworkers.  Excellent benefits.  Some managers and supervisors are excellent mentors.  University area is full of interesting activities/restaurants/etc.
cons:
Lots of people don't pull their weight, which is OK since many areas are overstaffed.
Salaries are very not standardized--be sure to negotiate well and do your research before accepting a number if hired

job_title: Senior Program Manager in New York, NY
pros: The project management teams at Earth Institute are incredibly smart, adaptable and capable. There is a great sense of collaboration and commitment to producing high quality deliverables.
cons: HR, procurement and financial processes take an unacceptably long-time thanks to a very bureaucratic system. There is also pro-male culture in which 35-year-old men are advanced to senior positions. Women in identical roles are on average 55-year-old. Finally, financial systems are quite disorganized and opaque.

review_title: Good place for those who want to relax, bad for those who want to get anywhere...
job_title: Developer in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits and lots of time off.  Very relaxed environment for the IT department.
cons: Pay sucks compared to industry.  Lots of politics and favoritism.  Seniority-based advancement.  Very little recognition for a job well done.  No incentive to try any more than just enough to get by.

job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros: The administrative teams can be amazing, hard working people who truly care about the students and delivering a great program.
cons: It can feel like there is a class system dictating that administrators have less to contribute to the program and overall success of the school than faculty. Though faculty are certainly knowledgeable and many are truly awe-inspiring, it can be demoralizing to be treated as a second class citizen.

review_title: Interesting place to work. Low pay. Few opportunities to promote. Poor mentorship.
job_title: Associate Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros: Columbia has good benefits and gives the opportunity to interact with bright people.
cons: The mentorship is poor or inexistent with lack of motivation. Very low pay, even below NIH recommended pay rate. Lack of opportunities to promote and to develop as an independent researcher.

review_title: Need to hire more competent staff
job_title: Grants Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Flexible working environment and good name in your resume. That’s all I have. I don’t have 20 words to write so what should I do?!!!
cons:
Incompetent staff especially mid and high level managers and directors which is also reflected on their choices of operational level employees!
So much politics make you feel like you are working in a third world institution not an Ivy League university !!

job_title: Instructor in New York, NY
pros: You get a job here, it looks great on your resume, pays pretty well, and they are so desperate for instructors in most departments, it's easy to get hired
cons: They are so desperate because there is no supervision/mentoring, you had better know what you are doing or you will be lost, make sure they give you a class you are right-on knowledge wise, the students are arrogant and will savage you in evaluations if you show a moment of weakness

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: This is a very wonderful place to work in and the benefits are excellent.  There are many wonderful people that you will meet that work here.
cons: This would be a better place to work in if promotions were given based on your work and your educational experience and not based on how nice you are to the boss.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits, good amount of paid vacation days
cons: Highly stressful competitive environment. Low support from managers and higher ups. favoritism is prevalent.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Benefits at Columbia University are top notch. Great vacation benefits, if you are able to take time off. Multiple medical plans to choose from.
cons: Poor management, and general lack of leadership. Most departments are so siloed that the right hand has no idea what the left hand is doing.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Autonomous work environment; Great benefits; Mission driven work; Very collaborative work environment; Community oriented; Good learning opportunities; Hands-on learning opportunities; Diverse, accomplished, intelligent co-workers
cons: Not much opportunity for growth or promotions or salary increases if one doesn't have a higher degree; Lack of mentoring; Very  limited professional development opportunities; Often a work overload

job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros: Casual and comfortable environment.  Great to work at a prestigious institution with some of the greatest minds in the world.  Meet all kinds of interesting people and you can't hep but become more worldly
cons: Pay.  It's not al all comparable to the real world.  Growth is limited.  People tend to stay at Columbia and not new opportunities ever present themselves.  You stagnate

review_title: Former software engineer for Columbia University
job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Great Benefits...first class educational atmosphere. Generally good employee-manager rapport. First-class employer training programs. Access to first-rate country-wide ivy league network.
cons: Elitist attitudes. Managerial misconduct.. Human Resources incompetence and unwillingness to pursue managerial misconduct. Outdated computer hardware and sometimes software. Too much bureaucracy...this is what happens when you have billions of dollars at stake I infer.

review_title: Great University but non-MBA department are not well-managed
job_title: Graduate Student in New York, NY
pros:
Great staff working here and a lot of promising international students. 
Great location in the NYC, people get Columbia subsidised housing
Great name of the university for your resume
cons:
The neighbourhood is not really kids friendly, many staff families live outside New York and commute.
Housing is great, but mostly small apartments.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Columbia is an intelligent and collegial environment. You will find students and colleagues alike who are ready to engage in interesting and challenging conversations which makes it an intellectually stimulating place to work.
cons: Columbia is a very large institution and at times it can be very hard to connect with the many parts of the university.

job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros: Great work environment with wonderful colleagues. There were many opportunities for professional development and a lot of support from my managers and peers. Overall, good benefits--excellent vacation day allotment.
cons: Low salaries (though possibly higher than other universities) with no room for flexibility. No performance-based incentives and, unfortunately, there isn't much room for career advancement. To be fair, I think this is generally what you expect when you take a job in higher ed!

review_title: Don't work in IT at Columbia; avoid.
job_title: IT Professional in New York, NY
pros:
- Tuition re-reimbursement (starting after a few years)
- Lovely Campus
cons:
- IT staff are shuffled into the worst work spaces; cubes, basements with no natural light
- Pay is FAR below industry standards
- Politics, Politics, Politics...   getting ahead has nothing to do with hard work or achievement.  Getting ahead has to do with covering for others incompetence

job_title: Center for Career Education Staff in New York, NY
pros:
-Tuition Exemption Program
-Some great students and colleagues
-Decent hours but can be early mornings/late nights if you're involved in campus recruiting & late night events
cons:
-Politics at the top is absurd. It's run poorly and with the self in mind. 
-Students are saying it's declining.
-Physical environment is hazardous with mold and mice infestations 
-Leadership is threatened by talented younger professionals that work there so they almost incite hardworking, talented individuals to leave CCE
-Poor technology and leadership

job_title: Systems Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Established institution with growth. I feel like I can learn a lot from my peers. They encourage additional opportunities for learning. If you do not plan to stay very long, having Columbia University on your resume still looks great.
cons: Administration is very corporate in its approach to school business, perhaps because this is a private institution. Difficult to separate work from personal time. Elitist attitude by some staff and faculty, but particularly students. Salary is average and raises seem rare since new construction is in progress.

job_title: Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits. Regardless of how demanding your job could be, management is very conscious of work/life balance. Even thought i did not work  directly with students there was that feel good vibe working at an Ivy league school
cons: Depending the size of the department you work for, opportunity of growth can be very limited. Some departments are just structure certain way, that do  not leave any room to move up unless someone above you leaves.

review_title: Confessions of a Poor Grad Student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Great place to be a grad student, if you have a good adviser. the University is filled with smart people and there are a ton of interesting activities and the neighborhood is great.
cons: How long you are here is highly dependent on a number of factors, including, but not limited to your advisor, funding, and the group/department you are in. There is the occasionally the feeling of lots of red tape when trying to implement something new.

review_title: Very fulfilling and professionally enriching experience
job_title: Associate Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros: Good work-life balance, flexibility with work hours and work from home benefits. Good potential for growth as a researcher with good academia outreach.
cons: Salary is low for the location. Health benefits are mediocre for the monthly premium paid.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The University supports and encourages their staff.  I have found many opportunities for building skills and knowledge.  There is good communication and i fell that they listen to their staff..
cons: It is a very large organizations, so there are many policies and procedures in place that you need to follow to accomplish what you would like to do.

review_title: Excellent Benefits, but Too Much Bureaucracy
job_title: Leasing Services Specialist in New York, NY
pros: The education benefits! All of the tuition for my masters degree was taken care of, so you MUST take advantage of this benefit. Also, lots of vacation and unlimited sick days is nice. Great work-life balance,
cons: Unfortunately, so many departments in Columbia are so deeply buried in bureaucracy that is becomes really difficult to get things done. When messages are funnelled down to someone from 3 or 4 levels up, sometimes communication gets screwed up.

review_title: Good university to work for but internal operation is not on par with external brand reputation
job_title: Professor in New York, NY
pros: Great brand reputation. Bright students and colleagues. Beautiful campus. Generous benefits. Neighborhood offers excellent living quality for faculty members.
cons: Poor facilities (classrooms, cafeterias, etc.). Administrative support structure (IT, student services, audio-visual, HR online, etc.) is very poor. Culture and values vary a lot across schools. School for faculty children has very limited space due to 50 percent of seats conceded to neighborhood.

review_title: It's a great place if you make it work for you
job_title: Project Manager in New York, NY
pros: Overall, it's a great learning environment and gives you access to very high level people. I found my department to be very flexible and hands off when it came to managing staff. I enjoyed it because you are pretty much on your own.
cons: In my department there was very little supervision and this can be a downfall when you need some guidance.

review_title: So far the company is a fine company to work with.
job_title: Porter/Clerk in New York, NY
pros: It's such an amazing and most interesting place to work I worked as a casual worker where I met so many positive and professional people  with great attitudes. The professors and students worked so hard to reach there goals it really it just made me no that furthering your education is very important.
cons: To be very honest I can't say nothing bad about the company because the company is do impressive to me.

review_title: It's not the company its the people. Once employed you are transformed into a robot or fired. Everyone is stressed.
job_title: Administrative Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: If you're in the union you will receive an annual raise
cons: There's no teamwork, it's like crabs in a barrel. What's funny is this is a teaching institute but management doesn't believe in teaching anything.

job_title: Assistant Watch Engineer in New York, NY
pros: Great people and facility. Great benefits they really helped me progress in my life.
cons: They wanted me to move up into more of a manager type roll. i was happy being an operator. Things became difficult so I left.

review_title: Great casual employment opportunity and a quick way to earn cash
job_title: SAT Tutor/Translator in New York, NY
pros: Translations are one-time commitments and you are emailed when a client requests translation in one of your proficient languages. There is thus no regular time commitment unless you are a tutor, and a lot of clients are willing to come on the Columbia campus.
cons: If you are not a tutor, you won't have regular pay. Also, for translations you are required to go in the office to sign off the notarization of each document.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
- School has good reputation - will look good on a resume
- Professors are intelligent - you can learn a lot from the more socially adept ones
cons:
- Much higher emphasis on research than teaching
- Most profs look at grad students as a source of cheap labor
- Classes at grad level are mostly a waste of time 
- Little to no management - difficult to find any important information about requirements
- Very poor at helping grad students get jobs in industry

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: There are some truly brilliant people that you will be surrounded by. The hours are not too demanding usually and the pay isn't terrible. Also its nice to be able to work your way around the faculty to find an interesting research group. Environment is generally stressfree. Beautiful Campus and love the city
cons: Work can be slow and frustrating as it is research. Different PI's will treat you differently. Difficult to branch in from outside of the university

job_title: Child Specialist in New York, NY
pros:
Good community of really caring professionals that support each other.
Very rewarding relationship with families.
On going trainings.
Staff wellness events.
Good benefits.
cons: The biggest downside is the burocracy with wich everything works. It takes too long to approve anything . It takes two months to hire anyone.

job_title: Graduate Student In Physics in New York, NY
pros: In NYC, plenty of good projects to work on, not much interdepartmental competition. Access to some of the smartest physicists in the field
cons: Stingy with everything related to compensation. Expect to have to work hard and argue for funding for conferences and any other non guaranteed benefits that graduate students in other similar programs will receive automatically

job_title: PhD Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Columbia pays students well compared to most other universities. Much of the grad student experience is dependent on department and advisor, and in my case both of these have promoted an excellent work-life balance and work environment.
cons: Columbia doesn't pay as well as nearby institutions where students face similar cost of living. Further it has actively fought to prevent students from unionizing.

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Unparalleled access to academic resources. The environment is exciting and fast paced. The upper west side of NYC is a great location to work.
cons: Office space is tight and the 18-19th century buildings are not really conducive to collaboration. One can feel isolated at one of the largest research institutions in the world.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros: The people are great to work with, collegiate environment, opens up the window to building new connections and opportunities, enjoy the opportunity to work with other people across different discplines
cons: Very stagnant academic environment, too many postodocs hanging around hoping for an academic job to open, not enough alternatives for a career outside academia discussed, lack of diversity in engineering especially women and minorities, wish for more opprotunities to grow and improve soft skills outside of the laboratory.

review_title: I had a decent experience working at Columbia
job_title: Dodge Front Desk Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Columbia is a very prestigious institution. I got to meet a lot of interesting people. The manager is very good with giving employees very flexible hours.
cons: The pay is low compared to other jobs that you can do at Columbia. There is little personal growth with the job. Most people who do this job do it for the money. Students can be difficult to work with at times.

job_title: Course Assistant in New York, NY
pros: very flexible in working hour and place. Learn a lot more than being a student. Get practice in documentation preparation and learn skills in communication with others.
cons: Low salary, workload can easily exceed the 20 hour/week cap depends on course. Have to work during weekends, actually a lot of work is done in weekends.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in East Orange, NJ
pros:
--Great educational benefits such as tuition exemption 
--Good Healthcare and Retirement Packages
cons:
--Salary could be better
--Occasional Hiring Freezes
--The less connected you are to the students, the more you get the business aspect of higher education

job_title: Network Technician in New York, NY
pros:
Large campus with 450+ buildings to manage
Diverse network and interesting field work
cons:
HR Training and personal development program  is poor and in 3 years I did not get the training I asked for in my original interview

Very political environment and nothing gets done the right and proper way

Coworkers are difficult to work with and managers have stated to not be ambitious and just follow orders.

Terrible place to build your career or work if you have ambitions and aspirations.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros: You get to have in-classroom experience and see what a typical day to day is like in a school setting, You get to "shadow" the lead teacher you are paired with and learn teaching methods.
cons: The school environment is toxic, nobody is nice to each other and there is little to no support. The parents are very aggressive and privileged. Depending on who the lead teacher that you are paired up with is you will either have a negative or positive experience

job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros: Vacation and demand of job are in line with compensation. Management is supportive of initiatives, but the process for promotion feels like a dangling carrot.
cons: Compensation is LOW. The 80% of the work done by 20% of the staff is in full effect here. Coworkers knowledge in other departments is extremely low.

review_title: Wonderful Faculty & Staff, but management does not recognize hard work or achievements
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Interaction with Faculty & Staff very open and helpful.
cons: No acknowledgment or merit bonus for excellent work.  2% increase across the board, if you are a good worker or a bad one.  Management does not care what happens.  Decisions are monetary based, with no regard for work ethics.

job_title: PhD Student in New York, NY
pros: It is great to be in NY as a PhD student. There are wonderful events in the university. The engineering school is small but there are very good professors. People are cooperative, there is no disturbing competition between the students. Many opportunities to collaborate with Brookhaven National Lab and other close by institutions.
cons: In some departments lab facilities are not sufficient. Pay is less than it;s supposed to be.

review_title: Columbia needs to make its Administration Staff feel more appreciated
job_title: Associate Business Process Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
* Vacation time is great
* Healthcare benefits are good
* Relaxed environment
* No Stress
* No Pressures
cons:
* You're basically going nowhere
* HR keeps changing benefits w/out notification
  --Tuition benefit has changed 5 times in the ONE year I've been ehre
* NO movement whatsoever
* Compensation SUCKS and they use "The Economy" as an excuse

review_title: very low wages and very slow and incompetent administration
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros: It is good for doing research and if you like New York City then you will enjoy the main campus on the Upper West Side/Harlem.
cons: The administration and IT is going to drive you nuts and you will struggle to make it to the end of the month.  Medical campus is located in a bad and dirty neighborhood. The metro station (168th Street) probably the worst in Manhattan.

job_title: Senior Researcher in New York, NY
pros: Decent pay and some work-life balance
cons: No career development opportunities, treats employees badly, does not reward loyalty, no progress in ranks, does not control direct supervisors at ground level.

review_title: Good work environment, great benefits, salary not too good
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Great benefits - including over 4 weeks of paid vacation. Unlimited sick days too.
Good friendly people, a nice environment to work at. Campus is amazing - lots of trees and greenery. Get to work with some very smart people.
cons: Salaries are low compared to the real world - also somewhat low when compared to other peer institutions. There is a decent bit of bureaucratic red tape here as well.

review_title: A dream job in many ways - but not perfect.
job_title: Professor in New York, NY
pros: Columbia is a top ranked university. It is highly regarded throughout the world and an employment here carries great prestige. There is a great intellectual environment here with many smart people and opportunities.
cons: Manu administrative structures seem to be outdated, making daily operations somewhat more burdensome than they should be for an institution of this caliber. Salaries both for administrative staff and faculty are relatively low, compared to other top tier institutions.

review_title: not as great as you imagine
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros: Big Research community, great reputation
cons:
There isn't a higher salary for postdoc (for being in NYC) as there is in others universities in the city (Cornell, Rockefeller, MSCCK, among others). Your salary and salary increase depends on your PI and usually they just want to pay the minimum.

job_title: IT Staff in New York, NY
pros: Access to a variety of different technology
cons: Office conditions were awful as far as I was concerned. Especially when they ship you off-campus into Harlem into what's basically a warehouse with long shared desks (no privacy and dangerous location across from train tracks, a gas station, and intersection). Not to mention the office is full of older folks who cough up phlegm and mucous all day. Gross. Good luck staying healthy. Likely in violation of several building codes (old dusty below-waist windows, giant lead door that swings open at any moment, could easily injure you). Meeting room was tiny and windowless, with no working equipment. Had to huddle around a tiny laptop in group meetings. Elevator service was shut down often as well, sometimes out of spite from the building workers. Co-workers routinely came into work sick as a dog. In fact, I was assigned to a desk where the ceiling had collapsed onto it. Then in the middle of the day, workers jack-hammered the roof directly above my head. I was told in an email, that work was going on that day and it "wouldn't be very noisy." Even further, I was told it wasn't "technically" a jackhammer, but a different type of tool. Great. The work culture is a game of who can refuse to do work for the longest and continue to make new excuses every week. I was amused by this for about a day. It slowly became very depressing. My colleagues played this excuse-as-to-why-they-haven't-been-able-to-work game over and over and over every single week, without fail. It was enough to drive you completely insane. Eventually I just quit for my mental and physical health. If you work here, and want to learn new stuff, you can, but only to a certain point. Everyone is afraid of the real cutting-edge technology and it's seen as impossible to understand by these dinosaurs, which basically leaves you fully screwed once you leave if you try to get into the private sector. Co-workers were abusive and everything is extremely political and based on words in emails, not actions. If you're a master manipulator you might do well here. New management constantly, and hired from consulting firms. They also force you to complete the windowless basement brainwashing that is ITIL. If you point out the toxic culture to HR you will find yourself deeper and deeper into an inescapable position, because everything is based on words and no one wants to lose their job. This place may have ruined my career, to be quite honest.

job_title: Project Manager in New York, NY

job_title: Director in New York, NY

review_title: Ivy League facade hides scientific dysfunction at CUMC campus.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scientist in Washington Heights, NY
pros:
The Ivy League name on your CV.  
The talented coworkers that have somehow been bamboozled into working here. 
The ability to work in NYC.
cons:
This is the worst place for scientific growth I have ever experienced. In my department the chair has a huge ego, bullies PIs and his trainees. His main talent lies in selling a lie like a slick salesman and amazingly he continues to recruit top notch postdoc and PIs. Our seminars are pointless because if anyone disagrees with the chair he just loudly and dismissively speaks over them. Past his prime, he simply does not understand some of the fundamental principles of the science in his department and he is too proud to realize what he doesn't know. Scientific growth is built from a collective knowledge of diverse experts and trainees and thrives through an open environment where people are not afraid to collaborate and learn. This does not happen here. The Chair is intimidated about what he doesn't know and overcompensates with a string of words that sound good but don't make sense and people let him get away with it, otherwise he will bully you into silence. 

It is incredibly embarrassing especially with visiting speakers to hear him speak or ask questions because it is clear he is not even a layperson in his understanding of anything other than what he studied in the peak of his career. The feeling of overall frustration is pervasive. Postdocs are depressed disillusioned and under-compensated. Good PIs that come deal with the chair by either refusing to engage or by quietly disagreeing behind his back or by openly voicing their frustration in negative ways and they eventually leave for better run institutions. All in all while there are amazing PIs and postdocs within this department the leadership is bad and this permeates the overall culture of our department. 

Core resources are shockingly unorganized with the least amount of competent staff needed to support researchers. 
Buildings are not climate controlled and desperately run down. Elevators don't work half of the time. 
Washington heights is not a pleasant area to work. 


All the reviews alluding to a terrible administration are also true. Don't be surprised if you don't get paid the first few months you work here. Grants administration? What grants administration? Expect to upload everything at the last minute with no real support. Expect to lose all your benefits if you are awarded a fellowship. Don't expect bridge funding to cover you even if your R01 is renewed because there's no reserve to support your lab. 
Pay is abominable for trainees and cumc housing and daycare are very expensive. 

All in all you can do well here but it is an overwhelming challenge. Academic science is hard enough in a wonderful and supportive environment so at CUMC the deck is stacked against you even more.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
Location is good (Manhattan)
Pretty campus to explore
Prestige of being associated with an Ivy
cons:
Grossly mismanaged from top to bottom
Administrative nightmare for students, staff, and faculty to navigate
Expensive housing nearby in WaHi and Morningside Heights
